subject: Creativity
title: Divergent vs. Convergent Thinking
description: A quick win: understand Divergent vs. Convergent Thinking.

hook.text: J.P. Guilford split creative thinking into two types in 1956. Every creative act uses both.

buildup.text: Divergent thinking generates many ideas â€” brainstorming, free association, wild possibilities.

discovery.text: Convergent thinking narrows to the best idea â€” analysis, judgment, selection.

twist.text: Schools overwhelmingly train convergent thinking. Divergent thinking peaks at age 5 and declines.

climax.text: The creative sweet spot is rapid switching â€” diverge to explore, converge to decide, then diverge again.

punchline.text: Creativity needs wild ideas AND sharp judgment. Neither alone is enough.
